title: How to Grow & Care for Jacaranda Trees

steps.title: Sow a jacaranda seed to grow a tree from scratch.
steps.content: Sow a jacaranda seed to grow a tree from scratch. Whether you purchased or harvested seeds from an established jacaranda, take a dry seed and soak it in water for 24 hours. This will help speed up the germination process. [1] X Research source Afterward, place the seed on a bed of potting soil in a container. Cover the seed with thin, well-draining soil and keep it moist. Wait 2 to 8 weeks for seeds to sprout. [2] X Research source Wait 8 months before transplanting the seedling outside or into a larger container. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Take a cutting from an established tree to propagate jacaranda.
steps.content: Take a cutting from an established tree to propagate jacaranda. If you know a friend or relative with a jacaranda tree, ask for a cutting of their tree. Use a pair of sterilized, sharp shears and select a healthy brand with at least three buds. Cut a 15 in (38 cm) segment at an angle just above a leaf node to encourage growth. Place the jacaranda cutting in water so only the bottom is submerged. Roots take 2 to 3 weeks to appear when left in a warm area with indirect sunlight. [4] X Research source Spring is the ideal time of year for propagation.

steps.title: Use an established seedling or tree to get blooms sooner.
steps.content: Use an established seedling or tree to get blooms sooner. If you live in a temperate or warm climate, get a jacaranda seedling from a local plant nursery or major retailer. [5] X Research source Jacaranda trees grow best in zone 10 on the hardiness scale. However, they can also survive in cooler areas—even regions with light frosts. [6] X Research source You may find jacaranda seedlings around the base of mature trees. If you can safely and legally dig up a seedling, you can transplant it into a container to grow your own. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Select a spacious outdoor area with direct sunlight for 6 to 8 hours.
steps.content: Select a spacious outdoor area with direct sunlight for 6 to 8 hours. Jacarandas can grow 25 to 50 ft (7.6 to 15.2 m) tall and 15 to 30 ft (4.6 to 9.1 m) wide. [8] X Research source Plant them in an area that receives direct sunlight for most of the year. [9] X Research source Plant the tree at least 15 ft (4.6 m) away from any nearby buildings, and avoid planting seedlings in the shade of other, larger trees. If you plant the jacaranda in a crowded space (e.g., under a patio or between narrow walls), it will not grow to its full size and may wither and become unhealthy.

steps.title: Use rich, well-draining soil to provide the tree with nutrients.
steps.content: Use rich, well-draining soil to provide the tree with nutrients. Jacaranda roots will suffer if they're not well-drained and require fertile, rich soil to provide them with plenty of nutrients. [10] X Research source Opt for sandy soil with a slightly acidic pH level (6-7.5). [11] X Research source However, you can also use well-draining clay or loam soils . Look for limestone or perlite ingredients in your soil. [12] X Research source If you're growing your jacaranda directly into the ground, look for a patch of soil that isn't prone to having puddles or other plants.

steps.title: Add 1 c (240 mL) of water if the soil is dry.
steps.content: Add 1 c (240 mL) of water if the soil is dry. Jacarandas only require water when the top 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) of the soil feels dry. Use your finger to inspect the soil. If it feels dry, pour a cup of water into the soil. If the soil is already moist, wait 7 to 9 days before checking it again. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Water the tree once a week in the summer and once a month in the winter.
steps.content: Water the tree once a week in the summer and once a month in the winter. Healthy jacaranda trees grow quickly but will wilt and possibly die without sufficient water. Use your finger to test the soil—if the top 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm) of soil feels dry, it's time to water it. Soak the soil until it is moist at a depth of 15 to 20 in (38 to 51 cm). Generally, you'll want to water the tree once a week in the spring, summer, and fall. [14] X Research source During the cooler winter months when the tree is dormant, water it once a month.

steps.title: Conserve water by placing mulch around the base of the tree.
steps.content: Conserve water by placing mulch around the base of the tree. To help the tree conserve water and keep the water from evaporating directly from the soil, set mulch around the tree's base. To achieve the best effect, lay the mulch about 2 in (5.1 cm) thick. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Feed the jacaranda twice a year with a well-balanced fertilizer.
steps.content: Feed the jacaranda twice a year with a well-balanced fertilizer. Adding fertilizer to your tree is a great way to increase its resistance to injury from diseases and insects. [16] X Research source Jacarandas prefer organic fertilizers containing either composted manure, bone meal, or blood meal. Use a fertilizer with an N-P-K ratio of 10-20-10 to promote sturdy, deep root systems. For mature trees, use an N-P-K ratio of 12-10-10 for leaf development and energy production. [17] X Research source For young trees, use 1 lb (450 g) of fertilizer per 1 inch (2.5 cm) of trunk diameter twice a year during the spring or late summer. For mature trees, use 1.5 lb (680 g) per 1 inch (2.5 cm) of trunk diameter twice a year during early spring and mid-summer. N-P-K stands for nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). [18] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid pruning and allow the branches to grow on their own.
steps.content: Avoid pruning and allow the branches to grow on their own. The branches of a jacaranda tree grow vertically and expand outward in all directions. Let the branches grow on their own; if you trim shoots or prune branches, you may permanently stunt the tree's growth. Whenever a jacaranda branch is pruned, it sends out vertical shoots, and so continual pruning will lead to an unnaturally tall and misshapen tree. [19] X Research source A jacaranda will grow into a roughly umbrella-shaped tree if left undisturbed.

steps.title: Rake the jacaranda's dropped flowers regularly to avoid odors.
steps.content: Rake the jacaranda's dropped flowers regularly to avoid odors. While a jacaranda’s brightly-colored flowers are beautiful, they have a pungent and foul smell when they start to decompose. They can also produce slime on your sidewalk and yards. So, to avoid a mess, rake up the flowers regularly. [20] X Research source Avoid planting a jacaranda tree in a position where its branches will arch over a swimming pool. When the flowers fall in autumn, they will blanket the surface of the pool and can clog the water filter. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Use insecticidal soap or horticultural oil to prevent pests.
steps.content: Use insecticidal soap or horticultural oil to prevent pests. Although jacaranda trees are strong, they're not immune to pests like aphids, spider mites, whiteflies, and sharpshooters. These pests can leave behind sticky residues and mold and drain vitality from the tree. Inspect the undersides of the leaves for tiny bugs or webbing. Spray insecticidal soap or horticultural oil on the leaves to treat them. [22] X Research source Use more potent chemicals or seek professional assistance if your tree is heavily infested. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Reduce watering if the leaves turn yellow.
steps.content: Reduce watering if the leaves turn yellow. If your jacaranda's luscious green leaves or purple flowers turn yellow, this is a sign of overwatering or poor drainage. To remedy this issue, reduce watering. Wait until the top 3 or 4 in (7.6 or 10.2 cm) are dry before watering again. Improve drainage by using raised soil beds or installing subsurface tile drains or vertical drains. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Prune leaves with brown spots.
steps.content: Prune leaves with brown spots. If you notice circular brown spots on the jacaranda's leaves, this indicates a fungal issue. Irregular shapes can indicate environmental stress, while yellow halos signify bacterial infection. Prune the affected leaves with sterilized shears to get rid of potential disease. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Add an absorbent layer to aerate the soil if the leaves drop.
steps.content: Add an absorbent layer to aerate the soil if the leaves drop. Overwatering or underwatering can cause a jacaranda's leaves to drop. Ensure the soil is moist but not soggy. If the soil is soggy, add an absorbent layer, like compost, to help aerate the soil. Additionally, if you've recently transplanted your tree, it could be shocked. Give the tree shade if this is the cause. [26] X Research source

steps.title: Add nutrients and provide more light for stunted flower growth.
steps.content: Add nutrients and provide more light for stunted flower growth. While jacarandas grow quickly, it can take 7 to 14 years before their flowers bloom. [27] X Research source However, if a mature jacaranda still isn't blooming, this could result from insufficient light, improper pruning, or nutrient imbalance. Ensure the tree gets full sunlight for at least 6 hours daily and increase your fertilizer's phosphorus intake. [28] X Research source If you need to prune a diseased branch, do so during early spring to help the tree heal faster. [29] X Research source

steps.title: Jacaranda trees are vibrant, drought-tolerant trees.
steps.content: Jacaranda trees are vibrant, drought-tolerant trees. Jacarandas can only thrive in subtropical to tropical areas like Argentina, Bolivia, and Brazil and select US locations like Hawaii, Southern California, Florida, and parts of Texas. They are mid-size trees known for their vibrant spring colors and purple or blue flowers. [30] X Research source Jacaranda bark is a thin, grayish-brown color that forms scales as it ages. These trees can live for as long as 200 years but average around 50. [31] X Research source Common varieties of jacarandas include Blue Jacaranda, Alba or White Christmas, Maroon, Bonsai Blue (shrub), Boxwood, Jacaranda Cuspidifolia (fern), and Yellow Jacaranda. [32] X Research source Jacarandas can grow from small shrubs to large trees. Blue Jacarandas are the most common variety; Boxwoods share the same appearance but are smaller. [33] X Research source Generally, Jacarandas take on a vibrant purple with a blue hue. However, Maroon or Purple varieties lack the blue hue. [34] X Research source

steps.title: Jacarandas can be grown indoors in a pot but will not flower.
steps.content: Jacarandas can be grown indoors in a pot but will not flower. If you want to enjoy the beautiful jacaranda without a blooming mess, you can! Transplant it into a pot two to three sizes larger than the pot you bought it in and use a sandy loam potting mix. Repot your tree every year into a slightly larger container. [35] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source Place it in an area of your home or a greenhouse with 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day. Use a 10-10-10 fertilizer 2 to 3 times a year during early spring, midsummer, and fall. [36] X Research source
